text: as I thought, it’s not failing anymore when I remove the aar I added manually.
Anyone got any decent links on restructuring inherited bad code etc?
Making progress, but can't help but feel like I should be thinking about it in a different way/approaching it from a different angle
you mean legacy code you inherited, or removing inheritance in classes
this book is awesome: <https://www.amazon.co.uk/Working-Effectively-Legacy-Michael-Feathers/dp/0131177052>

text: Sorry yeah, legacy code I inherited
<@U053PPGDC>: just found it free on google books too :slightly_smiling_face:
yeah, not saying you can’t get it elsewhere
:stuck_out_tongue:
Haha
Inherited this ~amazing~ app which is still under development by the original dev
~30 activities, 5 fragments
All activities inherit from "BaseActivity", which has ~2000 lines of badly written code
oh dear
:slightly_smiling_face:
Slowly ripping it apart haha
I’d say write a few espresso tests around it
Yeah that's the idea
:slightly_smiling_face:
Start writing tests and pulling code out into it's own classes for now
then yeah remove components bit by bit, replacing inheritance it with composition
Then start "optimising" it
Yeah
no silver bullets here :confused:
I know :disappointed:
Might just stick to basic unit tests for now though, instead of going the full espresso ui test suite :stuck_out_tongue:
unit tests will make things worse in your case <@U1LJG0Y03>
yep
you need as broad tests as possible

because it's legacy code, it is almost certainly highly coupled to everything. Unit testing that code will make changes very hard and slow. What <@U053PPGDC> said is for the best. Espresso tests will allow you to make changes without having to change your tests every so likely
then you can move on to unit tests, trust him he is the test guru here :stuck_out_tongue:
Makes sense
Ok hah :slightly_smiling_face:
Nice one
hey guys, quick question. is it possible to programmatically, during runtime, change the app's style attributes such as Primary Color?
<@U0UETGCJU>: themes are immutable *but* you can change the whole theme itself
I see. though I'm after changing specific attributes of the themes, such as Primary Color to a wholly arbitrary color
unless you want to try doing it with reflection which I would beg you not to do :stuck_out_tongue:
can you give me more info on your use case, I have done something similar and I think you might not need to change your colour this way
hmm
are you after having user selecatble primary and accent colours perhaps?
well it's quite simple to explain: I want to pick from my server the color of the app. and I should be allowed to pick whatever color I want for whichever attribute I want
per activity or  for the whole app?

for the whole app,
as if I were to apply an app-wide theme of primaryColor, accentColor, darkPrimaryColor, etc.
except these colors would be dictated anew on each load of the app
ok
on first launch, get theme attributes from server
then create your theme
my first comment would be that this is a bad UX but I guess you can't control that
then in each activity you subsequently launch use that theme
my guess is a seasonal promotion kinda thing
<@U09T8SFG8> yeah you're correct. but I'd test it locally first to make sure that the colors fit :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U053PPGDC> so what you're saying is - at runtime, it is not possible to change a theme. but it is possible to create one. 
so, create one for each activity.
did I get you right?
well
I guess you’re loading a config file of sorts
that usually happens on the splash screen
yup
so you can’t control that
I load things from the server, sort of a handshake
then you can have each activity inherit from a BaseActivity
that’s where you call setTheme before loading any resources
BaseActivity inheritance is a common practice anyway
indeed
what I don't understand is the parameter for the setTheme call
on which theme?
am I to create one @ runtime?
ah fuck
it takes a resId
my bad
all good man
<@U0UETGCJU>: are we talking about any color whatsoever or like 10 different ones?
Any1 has an idea what I can do? I already tried restarting, invalidating caches etc
Even tried removing `.iml` and `.idea` and re-importing
<@U09T8SFG8> a precise color, unknown to me
<@U0K1ALDQE>: are you using the terminal?
or the gradle manager in studio?
It works fine from terminal
one of the features of this library is to change colours at runtime <https://github.com/negusoft/GreenMatter>

attachments.title: negusoft/GreenMatter
attachments.text: GreenMatter - Android material theme backport and additional functionality.

Any way anyone can think of to pass in an animation to a FragmentTransaction instead of the resource ID?
Or to check if a resource ID(int) refers to an animation resource?
<@U1LJG0Y03>: there is the `@AnimRes` you can put on the method parameter that will compile time check that. <https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/annotation/AnimRes.html>
<@U1P8Z39HT|erick.major> has joined the channel
Ah nice
here's the blog post covering some others you can use: <http://tools.android.com/tech-docs/support-annotations>
